newsitem.title: ROMANIA: Romania agency cancels Azomures selloff contract.
newsitem.headline: Romania agency cancels Azomures selloff contract.

text.p: Romania's main privatisation agency said on Wednesday it had cancelled a contract to sell a 51 percent stake in listed fertiliser maker Azomures to a Romanian trading company.
"Euro Trading failed to pay for the purchase of the 51 percent stake and therefore, its contract with the State Ownership Fund (FPS) had been cancelled," a FPS statement said.
The FPS has control of most Romanian state companies.
The decision came after Euro Trading Chemicals SRL failed to meet a deadline on payment extended from early May.
Euro Trading officials, who could not be contacted since the sale agreement in February, were unavailable for comment.

The sale of the Azomures stake to Euro Trading was decided at a tender which aroused controversy with the rival bidder, Omnimpex Chemicals local trader, complaining factors other than price had allegedly been considered.
The FPS said the sale to Euro Trading was for 90,000 lei ($12.81) per share but did not give an overall purchasing price.
Azomures has a share capital of 209.5 billion lei.

Romania's main competition supervisor also launched an investigation into the 51 percent privatisation of Azomures, looking into alleged irregularities at the tender and a possible "economic concentration" in the fertiliser industry.
Euro Trading already acquired majority stakes in another two local fertiliser makers.
The FPS did not detail further plans for Azomures' privatisation after it had cancelled the Euro Trading contract.
But Omnipex said it was ready to start negotiations with the FPS for the sale of 51 percent.

"We are entitled to request to be invited by the FPS to negotiate a sale-purchase contract for the 51 percent stake in Azomures, in line with the contract between Omnimpex and the FPS concluded during the tender," an Omnimpex statement said.
Azomures is a Bucharest bourse first-tier stock heavily traded since it joined the exchange last January.
Traders said the cancellation of the privatisation contract would have little if any impact on Azomures bourse trading.

"There is keen interest in Azomures, investors will still stick to its shares no matter what," a trader said. "And even if the news were to influence trading it would do so for the better." ($=7,086 lei)
-- Luli Popescu, Bucharest Newsroom 40-1 3120264 ($ = 7025 Romanian Lei)
